items.description: North Devon coast from Hartland Point to Lynmouth
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message: The risk of flooding from the sea has now reduced and tidal water levels for upcoming tides have fallen below levels of concern.

items.description: West Bay Harbour
Tidal River Avon at Bristol, Pill and Shirehampton

floodArea.county: City of Bristol, North Somerset, South Gloucestershire

items.message:
This flood alert remains in place for the evening high tide on 15/08/2022.  Forecast high water is at 22:45 this evening 15/08/2022 with a level of 7.35 mAOD with force 3 south westerly wind. All times are local and refer to the high water time at Avonmouth. Flooding to roads and farmland is possible an hour either side of the high tide along the tidal River Avon from Sea Mills to Conham in Bristol and between the Avonmouth Bridge and Shirehampton Park including Pill and Shirehampton.  We continue to monitor the situation and our incident response staff are closing flood gates and checking defences.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and be careful along promenades, coastal footpaths and roads.
This message will be updated on Tuesday 16/08/2022 when this flood alert is likely to be removed as tides fall.

items.description: Wye Estuary in Gloucestershire
The north Norfolk coast from Old Hunstanton, to and including Cley
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely between 09:00am and 11:00am tomorrow, Tuesday 16th August.  We expect to see water on roads and paths to beaches and on the quays in Brancaster, Burnham Overy, Holkham, Wells and Blakeney.  The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Wells of 3.51 mAODN at 10:00, on Tuesday 16th August, which is 0.21m above tide tables, wind Force 3, westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables).  Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.  We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate.  We will update this message by 12 noon tomorrow, Tuesday 16th August.

items.description: The north Norfolk coast from East Cley to Kelling Hard, including Salthouse
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely between 09:00am and 11:00am tomorrow, Tuesday 16th August.  We may see water on Beach Road at Cley, and Beach Road at Salthouse, and footpaths in the marshes may also become inaccessible.  The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Wells of 3.51 mAODN at 10:00, on Tuesday 16th August, which is 0.21m above tide tables, wind Force 3, westerly.  (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables).  Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.  We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate.  We will update this message by 12 noon tomorrow, Tuesday 16th August.

items.description: Mersey Estuary at Warrington
items.message: This Flood Alert has been removed. River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold on 15/08/22. We will continue to monitor the situation and reissue the alert if necessary. Please be aware of your surroundings and keep up to date with the current situation.

items.description: Wyre estuary from Fleetwood and Knott End to Little Eccleston
items.message: The weather is more settled and no further impacts are expected.

items.description: Christchurch Harbour
Tidal Thames riverside from Putney Bridge to Teddington Weir
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: Greater London, Hammersmith and Fulham, Hounslow, Richmond upon Thames, Wandsworth

items.message:
River levels are expected to be high as a result of spring tides.

The forecast high tide at Richmond is 4.64mAOD at 18:15 on Monday 15th August 2022.

Flooding of low-lying roads and footpaths is expected, which may exist for one to two hours either side of high tide. Flooding of properties is not expected.

We believe there is a possibility of flooding for Putney Embankment (SW15), Chiswick Mall and Strand on the Green (W4), Thames Bank at Mortlake (SW14), Ranelagh Drive (TW1), Friars Lane and Water Lane (TW9), Riverside and The Embankment at Twickenham, and the Towpath below Teddington Lock. 

Astronomical tide levels are falling. The river flow at Teddington Weir is very low for this time of year at 7 cubic metres per second and is steady. We anticipate the flows to remain very low for at least the next few days.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

This message will be updated by 21:00 this evening, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Somerset coast at Porlock Weir
items.message: This Flood Alert has been removed. We will continue to monitor the situation and reissue the alert if necessary.

items.description: The Essex coast from Clacton to and including, St Peters Flat and the Colne and Blackwater estuaries
items.message:
Levels are now well below the flood risk thresholds. The forecast is for no current flood risk from high tides. There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away. 
 Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.  We will continue to monitor levels closely.

items.description: River Leen, Day Brook and Tottle Brook in Nottinghamshire

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Leen, Day Brook, Tottle Brook

items.message: We are expecting localised thunderstorms to pass through the area over the next few days. As a result, small, flashier rivers and streams may respond to this heavy rainfall. This message has been issued pre-emptively ahead of the predicted localised thunderstorms for today, 15th August 2022, tomorrow and Wednesday. Given the unpredictable nature of thunderstorms, there is low confidence in the exact locations, timings and impacts of rainfall at this point. Areas most at risk are low lying agricultural land, roads and footpaths close to small rivers and streams. Water levels could rise rapidly and potentially generate deep, fast flows. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are patrolling watercourses in the area and clearing weed screens. Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 16th August 2022 or as the situation changes.
